net.uniform.api

Interface Element

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    ElementWithValueConversion<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractElement, AbstractHTMLElement, Button, Checkbox, DatePicker, ElementWithOptions, Hidden, HTMLElement, Input, Multicheckbox, MultioptionInputElement, Multiselect, Radio, Select, Textarea

    public interface Element

    An Element represents any kind of item contained in a Form

    Every element has an id (unique and mandatory) and a label (optional).

    All elements are able to:
    • Hold a list of String values
    • Declare if the element is multivalue (otherwise the list of values will contain at most one value). For example, a Multiselect is a type of element that can hold many values
    • Define a type for their values to be converted later in the form (with getFormDataConvertedToElementValueTypes method)
    • Validate its own values with the getValidationErrors method
    • Hold a list of validators responsible of validating the element values in the previous method
    • Rendering itself into HTML with the render method
    • Hold an optional Renderer responsible of rendering the main HTML of the element in the render method
    • Define a default renderer to use when the default renderer is null
    • Hold a list of decorators for extending its rendered HTML in the render method
    • Hold a list of filters that are applied to any value before it's set to the element
    • Hold String properties indexed by name, to be used when rendering the element. Normally, a renderer will put all the properties in the main HTML tag as attributes, but this depends on the element and the renderer

    All property names will be converted to lower-case

    Unless explicitely changed with setProperty(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), the id and name HTML attributes of an element will correspond with the id of the element.

    A set of common elements are included in Uniform in the package net.uniform.html.elements

    The default abstract element implementation that you should use and extend is AbstractElement

    Author:
    Eduardo Ramos

        String getDescription()
        Returns the description of the element (never translated).
        Returns:

      • getLabelTranslated

        String getLabelTranslated()
        Returns the label of the element but, if translation is enabled (isTranslationEnabled()), tries to find its translation in the current TranslationEngineContext. If no translation is found, it returns the label value. This should be used by any class that needs the label of the element for the final HTML.
        Returns:
        Translated or original label depending on element configuration

      • getDescriptionTranslated

        String getDescriptionTranslated()
        Returns the description of the element but, if translation is enabled (isTranslationEnabled()), tries to find its translation in the current TranslationEngineContext. If no translation is found, it returns the description value. This should be used by any class that needs the description of the element for the final HTML.
        Returns:
        Translated or original description depending on element configuration

      • isTranslationEnabled

        boolean isTranslationEnabled()
        Indicates if the translation of label and description is enabled for this element. By default translation is disabled. This is changed with the setTranslationEnabled() method
        Returns:
        True if translation is enabled, false otherwise

      • setTranslationEnabled

        Element setTranslationEnabled(boolean enable)
        Enables or disables the element label and description translation. By default translation is disabled.
        Parameters:
        enable - Boolean indicating if the translation has to be enabled
        Returns:
        This element

      • setTranslationEnabled

        Element setTranslationEnabled()
        Enables the element label and description translation.
        Returns:
        This element

      • getValueType

        Class<?> getValueType()

        Returns the type of the values of this element, to be used when converting values in the form (for example in getFormDataConvertedToElementValueTypes method). Most element will return String.class Some elements will offer a setValueType method to change the value returned by this.

        If the returned type is null, the element will never by populated by a form, and its values will never be included in extracted form data with methods such as getFormData.

        Returns:
        Value type class or null

      • setValueType

        void setValueType(Class<?> valueType)

        Changes the value type returned by getValueType() method.

        This type is used in a form to do automatic value conversion in methods such as getFormDataConvertedToElementValueTypes.

        By default, all elements have String value type.

        This type should only be set to a type which any value set to the element (after validation and filtering) can be converted to.

        Conversion of simple types such as numbers is supported by a form. For any other complex type such as Date, the element can implement the ElementWithValueConversion interface to completely override the conversion of values.

        Not every element supports change of this type. For example, a Checkbox is always Boolean and DatePicker is always Date

        Parameters:
        valueType - New class for values of the element.

      • isMultiValue

        boolean isMultiValue()
        Indicates if this element is multi-value (for example, a Multiselect or Multicheckbox) or not. This is used by a form to determine how to extract data of its elements in methods such as getFormData
        Returns:
        True if the element is multi-value, false otherwise

      • getValue

        List<String> getValue()
        Returns current the list of values hold by the element. The return value can be null. Only multi-value elements will return a list of more than one value.
        Returns:
        List of values or null

      • getFirstValue

        String getFirstValue()
        Returns the first value hold by the element or null.
        Returns:
        First value or null

      • setValue

        Element setValue(List<String> value)
        Sets the list of values to be hold by the element. A single-value element will ignore all values but the first. This will never be called by a form on its own during data population, populate(java.util.List) method will be called instead
        Parameters:
        value - List of values or null
        Returns:
        This element

      • setValue

        Element setValue(String value)
        Sets a single value to be hold by the element. It's converted to a list of one value by the element. This will never be called by a form on its own during data population, populate(java.util.List) method will be called instead
        Parameters:
        value - Single value or null
        Returns:
        This element

      • populate

        Element populate(List<String> value)

        Sets the list of values to be hold by the element. This should only be used by a form during data population.

        This methods exists in order to make elements aware that the the data is being set by the form population (user input values), and be able to ignore the value if the element has the disabled property, or just ignore any value in special elements like Hidden, where the user should not be able to change the value of the element.

        A single-value element will ignore all values but the first.

        Parameters:
        value - List of values or null
        Returns:
        This element

      • getProperties

        Map<String,String> getProperties()
        Returns all the properties of the element indexed by key.
        Returns:
        All properties in a map, will never be null

        Indicates if the element has a value for the property (even null).
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        True if a value is set, false otherwise

      • setRequired

        Element setRequired(boolean required)
        Sets the required flag of this element to the given value. If an element is required, a RequiredValidator will be used in its validation even if it's not in the list of validators. By default, elements are not required.
        Parameters:
        required - Required flag
        Returns:
        This element

      • setRequired

        Element setRequired()
        Sets the required flag of this element to true. If an element is required, a RequiredValidator will be used in its validation even if it's not in the list of validators. By default, elements are not required.
        Returns:
        This element

      • isRequired

        boolean isRequired()
        Indicates if this element is required. If an element is required, a RequiredValidator will be used in its validation even if it's not in the list of validators.
        Returns:
        True if the element is required, false otherwise

      • getValidationErrors

        List<String> getValidationErrors()
        Validates the value(s) of this element with the list of validators and required flag.
        Returns:
        List of errors (may be empty) or null

      • isValid

        boolean isValid()
        Returns true if getValidationErrors() returns no errors
        Returns:
        True if element valid, false otherwise

      • validationPerformed

        boolean validationPerformed()
        Indicates if the validation has been performed with this element (getValidationErrors() method has been called).
        Returns:
        True if validation has been performed, false otherwise

      • clearValidation

        Element clearValidation()
        Sets the validation performed status of this element to false.
        Returns:
        This element

      • render

        List<SimpleHTMLTag> render()
        Renders the list of HTML tags of this element, using the set render or the default renderer if the set renderer is null. It also applies any decorators in the element, in list order. Renders the element without the context of a form, like calling render(net.uniform.api.Form) with a null form.
        Returns:
        List of HTML tags for the element, after decoration

      • render

        List<SimpleHTMLTag> render(Form form)
        Renders the list of HTML tags of this element, using the set render or the default renderer if the set renderer is null. It also applies any decorators in the element, in list order. The form is passed to the decorators of the element.
        Parameters:
        form - Form context for this element or null for no form context
        Returns:
        List of HTML tags for the element, after decoration

      • reset

        Element reset()
        Resets the values and validation state of the element. The value of a disabled element won't be reset.
        Returns:
        This element
